definition: to quarrel/to have a row/quarrel/CL:頓|顿[dun4]
to quarrel/to make a noise/noisy/to disturb by making a noise
to support/frame/rack/framework/classifier for planes, large vehicles, radios etc

sentences.english: Even bides such as a quarrel between husband and wife are brought to the peasant association.
sentences.chinese: 連兩公婆吵架的小事，也要到農民協會去解決。

sentences.english: Those who in quarrels interpose must often wipe a bloody nose.
sentences.chinese: 那些吵架的調停者必須時常抹鼻血。

sentences.english: The two sisters always quarrels like cat and dog.
sentences.chinese: 她們姐妹倆在一起就雞犬不寧，老是吵架。

sentences.english: And they're fighting over something so ridiculous
Family Quarrel The young newly- weds quarreled.
sentences.chinese: 家庭的爭吵一對年輕的新婚夫婦吵架了。

sentences.english: He interposed between the two women who were quarrelling.
sentences.chinese: 他在兩名吵架的婦女間進行調解。

sentences.english: Tom often quarrels with his brother.
sentences.chinese: 湯姆經常和他兄弟吵架。

sentences.english: And love of people quarrel, and the strangers speak from the heart.
sentences.chinese: 和愛的人吵架，和生疏人道口裏話。

sentences.english: Her opinion is so harsh sometimes. It can be.
sentences.chinese: 我們也吵架，因爲她的意見有時很尖刻。

sentences.english: I had an argument with my boyfriend yesterday. I'm bummed out.
sentences.chinese: 昨天我和男朋友吵架了，我很沮喪。

sentences.english: The recall many years ago, terrified parents quarrel Su Shu eues things.
sentences.chinese: 翩帕回想起多年前，父母吵架嚇壞蘇舒薇的事情。

sentences.english: Mary and John quarreled, but made up after a while.
sentences.chinese: 瑪莉和約翰吵架了，但不一會就和好了。

sentences.english: A quarrel only, with two people cry on each other's shoulder ended a noon.
sentences.chinese: 唯一的一次吵架，以兩個人抱頭痛哭一中午而告終。

sentences.english: He interposes himself between the two persons who are quarrelling.
sentences.chinese: 他在兩個吵架的人之間進行調停。

sentences.english: Sometimes we argue , but we mainly get along.
sentences.chinese: 我們有時會吵架，但是大部分的時候都處得很好。

definition: to be at loggerheads/to have a falling out
to be difficult with sb/to provoke disagreement/at loggerheads/to fall out with
to quarrel/to make a noise/noisy/to disturb by making a noise
to shout and scream (idiom); to kick up a fuss/to make a scene
to turn over old accounts/fig. to revive old quarrels/to reopen old wounds
to make trouble without reason (idiom); to be deliberately provocative
to part company/to split up/to break up
